newsitem.title: TURKMENISTAN: FEATURE - Turkmen patience with their leader wears thin.
newsitem.headline: FEATURE - Turkmen patience with their leader wears thin.

text.p: He is everywhere. On the street, in offices, on every banknote, the bland, fleshy face of Turkmen President Saparmurat Niyazov stares out from countless portraits across the desert nation of four million.
But the anger the impoverished Turkmens feel at Niyazov, known as "Turkmenbashi" or leader of the Turkmens, can be felt like the hot wind that blows off the surrounding Kara Kum desert.
For despite substantial reserves of natural gas and oil, most Turkmens find it hard to feed their families adequately.
Police now stand guard near the larger photographs and tawdry portraits -- diplomats say some unguarded pictures have been defaced.
The images, bleached by the sun, show Niyazov sitting next to a vase of flowers; in a traditional red cloak; in front of the United Nations headquarters in New York.
His cult has all but erased that of Soviet state founder Vladimir Lenin, one small statue of whom has been allowed to stand in a city park.
In the centre of the capital Ashgabat, a statue of Niyazov's mother carrying him as a child depicts him as a Turkmen Christ.
If Niyazov is not speaking on state television, men in sharp suits and women in long dresses and headscarves are singing his praises. Children recite poems in his honour.

Mosques, towns and roads are named after Niyazov who, like most other leaders in the former Soviet south, made a smooth transition from Communist Party boss to strongman leader after independence in 1991.
But save for his daily dash in a convoy of shiny foreign cars from the presidential palace to another in the cool hills above the city, the 56-year-old leader is rarely seen in public.
A new wall has been built within the tall iron railings which already surround the palace gardens to prevent passersby looking in.

Houses have been torn down around a new presidential palace being built by a French firm, which promises to be more opulent than the last. Locals say the demolition is because officials fear the buildings could provide cover for an assassin.

A whole strip of new hotels, their pastel colours and marble fountains a mix of Las Vegas and 1001 Nights kitsch, stand empty while Turkmens travel from across the desert country to Ashgabat to queue for a loaf of bread.
Supplies of subsidised food are drying up in state shops. State salaries of around $10 a month -- if they are paid -- go nowhere in the expensive private markets.

"I don't like to go out to shop now, the people in the queues are shaking with anger, I am afraid," said a Turkmen woman who did not want to be named. "The old have patience but not the young," she said.
No dissent or opposition is tolerated.

"May my tongue shrivel up and my bones turn to ashes if I betray my country or my president," is a stock phrase repeated throughout the day on state television and each morning before class by schoolchildren.
Diplomats and Turkmens say they know of no organised opposition inside the country. "It is very dangerous to meet and talk in an organised way," said a disenchanted Turkmen businessman.
But a growing list of sacked ministers and officials shows a touch of nerves at the top.

Niyazov fired a string of officials to try to shift the blame for this year's disastrous wheat harvest. Officially, the harvest was 600,000 tonnes short of the one million tonne target for 1996 -- but it could be even less.
Ashgabat buzzes with political jokes as bitter as the Turkmens' camelthorn tea.
A favourite is the "presidential striptease" -- a Niyazov portrait on the manat banknote is transformed into a person's behind by covering most of his face save for the double chin.
It is unclear whether the growing and surprisingly open anger will explode.
"There might be bread riots but there doesn't appear to be any real figure or idea to oppose Niyazov," said one diplomat.
The Turkmen businessman agreed. "People are starving in North Korea but nothing's changed there," he said.
Turkmenistan's main revenues from gas exports remain imprisoned in Russian pipelines, diverted to former Soviet neighbours who cannot pay.
Niyazov admits that not everybody can reap the benefits of Turkmenistan's huge natural resources.
"Not everyone can be rich," he said on state television. "Usually one in 10 is rich and the other nine must work for him."
